> So at turn t, with life span L, it will be there for L more turns, including turn t. So at turn t, after the turn, life span decreases to L-1 for next turn.

> Standard way: if at turn t, life span is L, then:
> 
> - During turn t, it is present.
> 
> - After turn t, life span becomes L-1.

> - When life span reaches 0, it disappears before the next turn.

> Standard snake movement: when the snake moves to a new cell, if no food, the head occupies the new cell, each body segment moves to the position of the previous segment, and the tail segment is left, so the snake has the same number of segments, but the last position is no longer part of the snake.

> 
> In terms of indices, if there are n segments, after move without eat, new head, and segments 0 to n-2 of old become segments 1 to n-1 of new, and old segment n-1 (tail) is removed.

> Let's clarify the mechanics.
> 
> Normally, when moving without eating:
> - Head moves to new cell
> - Each body segment moves to the previous position of the segment in front
> - Tail segment is removed
> 
> When eating food:
> - Head moves to new cell with food
> - Food is eaten, score increases

> Standard snake mechanics:
> 
> - Start with snake of length L, positions P0 to P{L-1}
> 
> - Move head to new cell C
> 
> - If C has no food, remove tail P{L-1}, so new positions: C, P0, P1, ..., P{L-2}  (L segments)
> 
> - If C has food, keep tail, so new positions: C, P0, P1, ..., P{L-1}  (L+1 segments)
>
